subject: resource/Separate_Baptists
object: The Separate Baptists were an 18th-century group of Baptists in the United States, primarily in the South, that grew out of the Great Awakening.The Great Awakening was a religious revival and revitalization of piety among the Christian churches. It covered English-speaking countries and swept through the American colonies between the 1730s and the 1770s. Three important preachers of the times were Gilbert Tennent (1703–65), Jonathan Edwards (1703–58), and George Whitefield (1714–70).
human_readable: The comment about Separate Baptists is that they were an 18th-century group of Baptists in the United States, primarily in the South, that grew out of the Great Awakening. The Great Awakening was a religious revival and revitalization of piety among the Christian churches. It covered English-speaking countries and swept through the American colonies between the 1730s and the 1770s. Three important preachers of the times were Gilbert Tennent (1703-65), Jonathan Edwards (1703-58), and George Whitefield (1714-70).

Based on the context information, I will evaluate whether the statement "The Separate Baptists formed during the Great Awakening in New England that began in 1734" is correct.

The answer is:

`{'output': 'no'}`

This is because the documents mention that the Separate Baptists emerged from the First Great Awakening (which was a broader movement), but they specifically mention that the movement started in north-central North Carolina, not New England. The context also mentions that the Separate Baptist movement in the South established itself first in north-central North Carolina as a result of the coming to that area in 1755 of a small colony of Baptists from Connecticut.

Additionally, while it is true that the Great Awakening began in the 1730s, the documents do not specify that New England was where it started. The Separate Baptists are mentioned as emerging from this movement, but their specific roots and location are discussed in more detail later on.
